messageBody:
I'm developing a web application, largely as TDD. I've got a number of
different objects where I have "real" implementation, and "mock"
implementation of an interface, to make unit testing easier. At this
point, I'd say that I have about 6-8 different interfaces that are
implemented as both real and mock. So far, I've dealt with this by
passing the appropriate implementation around as argument, starting from
each web request or Unit Test. When the system "running for real",
these objects could be singletons, or "globals initialized at servlet
start time".

In addition, I've got some information with is "request specific" (like
WHO is doing something).

I'm getting tired of having to pass some objects through 6-8 methods,
and it's making method signatures very ugly.

The question is, what do folks think about using ThreadLocal to create
"per request singleton-like" objects. By using a common base TestCase,
I could set up the TLS easily enough without overburdening the unit
tests, I think.

David
